ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A basic knowledge of intro statistics; regressions; estimators; inference; confidence intervals; some probability stuff. The math behind everything.
fundamentals of econometric analysis

This course gives an overview of topics in probability and statistics that are necessary for understanding econometrics, while also giving some insights into applications of statistical techniques in empirical research. Since there amount of topics to be covered is quite vast, the depth at which topics are treated varies. Thus, to get the most out of the course, it helps to spend a lot of time practicing the material itself as well as "adjacent" material from the textbook to get full grasp of the relationship between different statistical concepts.
From basic probability theory to hypothesis testing and inference. Think S&DS 241 and 242 combined in one semester
It was a strong introduction to probability and statistics; better intuition for probability and distributions and great applications of material
Moment generating functions, central limit theorem, Bayesian statistics, discrete distribution, continuous distribution, confidence level, hypothesis testing
I learned about the foundations of statistics from a mathematical perspective
Knowledge of foundational statistical concepts including Bayesian estimation and different kinds of distributions
I learned about the fundamentals of probability and basic statistics. I also learned how to apply these principles for research purposes
Learned how to code as well as probability theory.

The course is comprised of theory and practice. 

For practice, I learned some basics of R, including linear regression, data visualization, and hypothesis testing. The theory component is a more in-depth version of AP stat, so if you pay attention you'll be fine. The R coding practice is more valuable in my opinion. That part has gotten me to add more econometrics into my course planning.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The content was interesting and the sections were great. However, the psets varied tremendously in length and difficulty. One of them took maybe three hours, while there was another pset that took easily 40 hours and came out of nowhere (both across 2 weeks). Additionally, lectures were taught at a level that felt well above that of the course. By the middle of the semester, I would get more confused going to lecture than just trying to read the content in the textbook/lecture slides. One final critique was the lack of instruction in R/Phython - the psets expected us to use them without any instructions whatsoever, and learning how to do so alone was very time consuming and inefficient.

lecture notes are wonderful, yusuke is well rounded and the ta bennie is superb
the lectures could be a lot more engaging though.

The course serves its purpose well as a survey of probability and statistics for economics. The lecture notes are clear and well-organized. To improve the course, I think it would be helpful to have weekly problem sets that cover two lectures of material each rather than problem sets due every 2-3 weeks.

Strenghts: lecture slides are great, thorough enough to be helpful, and short enough to not feel like a textbook; the professor is organized and often does quick breaks for questions; TA Bennie is excellent, especially his review slides; the material is a good mix of theory and applications; I enjoy the (extremely) long psets about once a month, make sure to start early

Weaknesses: it can be fast-paced if you have no prior knowledge of the material, so beware

Strengths: Clear bounds on what the material is with relevant application, lots of instructor support
Weakness: it's challenging, you're going to have to do some work on your own, namely reading the textbook

Strength: the textbook is very good, TA is super helpful, problems in the Psets are very helpful to gain better understanding, midterms and finals are set to reasonable difficulty levels, coding section in problem sets are very useful and helpful.
Weakness: the pace of lectures are quite uneven, lectures could be more engaging, variables in the lecture slides can be labeled better. I dont understand a lot of things from the lectures, I study most of the content by reading through the textbooks by myself.

I think the material covers a lot of ground and ultimately gives a mathematical foundation of statistics. As such, I felt like I had a solid understanding of fundamental concepts by the end of the course. I think a more standardized/thorough walkthrough of necessary coding techniques would have been helpful.  The course was also sometimes so grounded in the math that it felt hard to naturally apply the concepts.

Strengths are that the course is well structured and the problem sets weight much more compared to other classes. Weaknesses are that Yusuke is a really nice professor but could be more engaging in his lectures. The pace of this class is also incredibly fast.
I may have preferred longer problem sets, as I felt I could have used more practice with some concepts especially the applications using R.
The theory was not explained that I felt was super conducive to learning all the information. And the coding felt like separate part of

Strengths: the content is clear and friendly to various studying styles: if you go to every lecture, you'll do well; if you just learn from the textbook and notes, you'll also do well.

Weaknesses: the material can feel a bit overwhelming for students who haven't had stats exposure before. For example there was a spike in difficulty after the first pset, and we had to put in a lot of effort to overcome that.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, not unless it's required for your major. If you're looking to learn statistics, definitely take 241/242 instead. It's not worth having to learn all the content on your own. It is nice to have an open notes final, though.
Yes
yes - take it if you must. pay attention in lecture and go to bennies sessions and you should fare fine
Yes. If you are interested in econometrics and statistics, it's a very helpful course to get an initial sense for what the field is about.
Great overview of statistics. Useful to any ECON major remotely interested in the material
Yes, it's generally a major requirement to those taking it, but it's very doable and interesting. A bit of a stats background on basic counting and types of distributions would be beneficial
Yes, the content is good. It would be better if lecture slides can be more structured, and variables in the slides can be labeled better.

The course is definitely fast-paced and can feel like a lot to handle at the beginning given how mathematical it is. However, once I got used to the style of the class, I did come out with a pretty solid understanding of most of the material. You may need the course for your major anyways.
Yes if it is required for the Econ and Math major.
Yes. This was my favorite class I've taken so far. I found the material interesting and learned a ton.
No, unless required for major

Yes, I think it's better than econ 117 and the right amount of difficulty. For people interested in econometrics, the course is a good package of content. I now feel more confident taking future s&ds classes, having worked through the basics with this class. For econ & math majors, I think it's really worth it to pay attention in 135 and learn the material well.
